recipe.name: Pork Tenderloin with Creamy Marsala Sauce
recipe.description: Juicy pork tenderloin smothered in a Creamy Marsala Sauce with Mushrooms. It's like gravy - but even better because the sauce has beautiful layers of flavour in it from the Marsala. Using wine in cooking is how posh restaurants make such beautiful sauces! Use this Marsala Sauce for other proteins like chicken, veal and beef.
recipeIngredient: 5 oz / 150g   mushrooms (, sliced (I used Swiss Brown))
1/4 cup finely chopped shallots or onion
2 cups / 500 ml  chicken broth (, low sodium)

recipeInstructions.text: Sprinkle pork with salt and pepper.
recipeInstructions.name: Sprinkle pork with salt and pepper.

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in an ovenproof skillet over high heat. Sear on all sides until nicely browned.
recipeInstructions.name: Heat oil in an ovenproof skillet over high heat. Sear on all sides until nicely browned.

recipeInstructions.text: Place in the oven for 15 minutes for the faintest blush of pink (pictured) or 18 to 20 minutes for no pink. See Note 4 for internal cook temperatures.
recipeInstructions.name: Place in the oven for 15 minutes for the faintest blush of pink (pictured) or 18 to 20 minutes for no pink. See Note 4 for internal cook temperatures.

recipeInstructions.text: Remove pork from skillet onto a plate, cover with foil and set aside in a warm place while you make the sauce.
recipeInstructions.name: Remove pork from skillet onto a plate, cover with foil and set aside in a warm place while you make the sauce.

itemListElement.text: Melt 1 tbsp butter in the same skillet over high heat. Cook mushrooms until browned, then remove.
itemListElement.name: Melt 1 tbsp butter in the same skillet over high heat. Cook mushrooms until browned, then remove.

itemListElement.text: Reduce heat to medium high, melt 1 tbsp butter,. Add onion and garlic, cook for 2 minutes or until onion is softened. Add flour and mix.
itemListElement.name: Reduce heat to medium high, melt 1 tbsp butter,. Add onion and garlic, cook for 2 minutes or until onion is softened. Add flour and mix.

itemListElement.text: Add marsala, cook until mostly evaporated (about 1 minute). Add tarragon and chicken broth, whisk until dissolved. Bring to simmer and cook until the liquid reduces by half - 3 to 5 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Add marsala, cook until mostly evaporated (about 1 minute). Add tarragon and chicken broth, whisk until dissolved. Bring to simmer and cook until the liquid reduces by half - 3 to 5 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Add cream and mix, then return the mushrooms and pork into the skillet as well as juices pooled on the plate. Simmer for 1 - 2 minutes until the sauce thickens into a thin gravy consistency (it will thicken more as you serve).

review.reviewBody: I short-circuited the recipe a bit.  I sliced the raw tenderloin into one inch thick pieces, browned it in olive oil and finished cooking it on top of the stove over medium heat.  Followed the rest of the recipe after that step.  It came out great!  The sauce didn't thicken as much as I would have liked.  Next time I'll use a bit more flour.
This was delicious. Pork was cooked perfectly. I will double up on the meat next time as I had a lot of sauce. I added a tbsp of minced tarragon and 1 tsp of dijon. This will be on repeat.

What a fantastic recipe! I mostly followed the recipe but I did marinade the tenderloin with a herb rub and felt like it gave the dish an extra layer of depth to all the lovely flavors.  I also didn't have tarragon and Nagi was right,  the sauce is still spectacular without. We are definitely adding this to our repertoire.

Just made this for dinner, didn't have quite the number of fresh mushrooms so rehydrated some ceps from the pantry, and used the liquid to make up the stock.  Used pork rump steak.  Hubby the mushroom hater just told me  "he knew it was full of mushrooms but it was super yum!"
This was amazing. Definitely added to the let's have again list

This is an excellent recipe. Very easy and the outcome is delicious! I didn’t have fresh tarragon but I had fresh thyme and worked well. Thanks for suggesting a sweet wine. My husband was hesitant but agreed it was perfect. Will definitely make this again.
Excellent recipe! No modifications needed. I’ve made this twice so far. Yum!!
Been looking for a recipe like this! Made with pan fried scotch fillets and subbed tarragon for sage. Super indulgent and super good.
This was so good, will be my go to marsala sauce from now on
Deeeelicious! You were right about that sauce - my mouth is STILL dancing! Hubby loved it too!

I will definitely be using this marsala sauce recipe….I’ve tried many with chicken and pork, but tonight with pork tenderloin….it was a hit m!  My son is a chef and if he gives his taste buds approval, it’s a definitely a keeper!  I prefer and used basil leaves, not tarragon.

I had never heard of pork marsala, only chicken Marsala.  This sounded interesting so thought I’d give it a go.  Oh boy is this a keeper!  Pretty simple and the flavors are amazing!  Every week my husband continues to request this dish!
